              2003-04     2004-05       2005-06       2006-07       2007-08
                                                                                                                                     year                         preserving and protecting the environment was a key concern for gold coast residents who responded to council’s bold future survey, and
                                         year
                 –– make decision (<20 days) –– make decision (<40 days)                                                                                          council has acted to preserve one of the region’s environmental jewels, purchasing tipplers resort on south stradbroke island. funded by the
                                                                                                                                                                  open space preservation levy, the $7 million acquisition will help to protect the 22-kilometre south stradbroke island from over-development
                                                                                                                                                                  and help conserve the area for future generations. one of only 15 sand islands in the world, it is close to the moreton bay marine park and is
                                                                                                                                                                  home to 238 species of animals and plants, including threatened species such as loggerhead and green turtles. council’s plan is for tipplers
                                                                                                                                                                  precinct to become a family friendly eco tourist destination. as part of the acquisition, four camping grounds will be refurbished to provide a
                                                                                                                                                                  nature-based camping experience, with the impact of visitors to the island to be minimised by the:
                                                                                                                                                                  y use of recycled water
                                                                                                                                                                  y recycling of all waste
                                                                                                                                                                  y use of energy-efficient barbeques and solar generated electricity, and
                                                                                                                                                                  y construction of an ecologically sustainable sewerage treatment plant.



                                                                                                                                                                     “we’re considered newcomers – and we’ve been here 30 years. i have four children and they all grew
                                                                                                                                                                     up here. the island is so precious to maintain.”
                                                                                                                                                                     catherine biggs south stradbroke island resident


                                                                                                                                                                  couran cove, south stradbroke island




                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             gold coast city council annual report 2008-09 75

   our performance // our governance


                                                                             what we mean by
council chambers, bundall road, surfers paradise
                                                                             governance
                                                                             corporate governance involves the control and management of an or-
                                                                             ganisation to achieve its objectives. it encompasses decision-making and
                                                                             implementation, optimisation of performance, and how the organisation is
                                                                             directed, reviewed and held to account.
                                                                             the australian national audit office recognises six main principles support-
                                                                             ing better practice governance. these are leadership, integrity, commitment,
                                                                             accountability, integration and transparency. council's corporate governance
                                                                             framework details the strategies, policies, systems, processes and procedures
                                                                             which reinforce these principles. it ensures our objectives are being achieved
                                                                             efficiently and effectively, ultimately delivering community value.


                                                                             highlights
                                                                             in planning for the future growth and development of our city, we have
                                                                             been working to strengthen our organisational capability. we have initiated
                                                                             programs to update and streamline our information technology systems,
                                                                             introduced strategies to protect our critical business functions, and focused
                                                                             on workplace change to re-shape our organisational culture.
                                                                             key projects which progressed during 2008-09 included our:
                                                                             y bold future vision, which has involved members of the community
                                                                               in helping to shape the future of the city for the next three decades
                                                                             y walking the talk initiative, which is translating our
                                                                               corporate values into positive actions
                                                                             y corporate plan 2009-14, designed to deliver the first
                                                                               five years of our bold future vision, and
                                                                             y information management improvements, which will help
                                                                               to protect our critical systems and data, streamline our
                                                                               property and regulatory processes, and enable information
                                                                               to flow seamlessly across council’s key business areas.


                                                                             addressing our
                                                                             challenges
                                                                             an increasingly complex operating environment, rapid advances in tech-
                                                                             nology, continuing growth of our city and an uncertain economic climate




      5.4
                                                                             are just some of the challenges facing council’s operations. we are commit-
                                                                             ted to ensuring that we:




                                                   our
                                                                             y encourage community participation in governance
                                                                               through equitable political representation
                                                                             y maintain a sustainable financial position that allows us to
                                                                               provide a high standard of service to the community




                                                   governance
                                                                             y ensure sustainable benefits from well-planned business initiatives
                                                                             y provide an effective exchange of knowledge and information across
                                                                               council, and between council, the community and other stakeholders
                                                                             y collect, handle and manage information effectively
                                                                             y deliver internal services that reflect best value and ensure
                                                                               efficient allocation of resources and services.
                                                                             y maintain a workforce that is motivated, productive and enthusiastic
                                                                             y provide a safe and healthy workplace, and




                        28.4%
                                                                             y demonstrate organisational values that reflect
                                                                               our corporate standards and policies.

   selecting new aab members                                                                                                                                                                  *for 2007-08, gold coast water activities were not
                                                                                                                                                                                              subject directly to internal audit activity. this decision
   as an advisory committee of council, the aab had to be re-established following the march 2008 local government elections. this                                                            reflected the significant reform process being under-
   involved detailing the roles of aab members and publicly advertising positions to allow for merit-based selection of members. while                                                        taken, which included review by state government
   existing board members are able to be reappointed, at least one board member is replaced during each council term. the current                                                             agencies.
   external professional members of the aab have been appointed for the 2008-2012 term of council.

our performance  our governance                                                                        our performance  our governance




 5.4.3 key performance
 indicator (kpi)
  level of stakeholder satisfaction
 with information and knowledge
 management processes
  control objectives for information and
 related technology (cobit) framework
 the annual independent review against the well recognised control
 objectives for information and related technology (cobit) framework
 has shown that movement towards the desired maturity status is
 evident across all principles. significant progress in addressing previ-
 ous audit actions also has been made, with all of the previous nine
 outstanding actions having been addressed. the independent review
 of the information management processes identified good progress
 against the maturity model established in 2006. this is due largely to
 the implementation of the electronic document and records manage-
 ment solution (ispot) across council, wider corporate access to the
 electronic system and the rollout of record keeping/ispot training.

 control objectives for information and
 related technology (cobit) framework

                                                                                                                                                                                                                       gold coast city council annual report 2008-09 103



                                                                  introduction
                      wastewater treatment plants are vital
                       elements of our city’s infrastructure.
                                                                  council’s most significant business units, with multi-million dollar
                                                                  operating budgets and assets, are gold coast waste management
                                                                  and gold coast water. they were established under the local
                                                                  government act 1993, and its principles for commercialised local
                                                                  government businesses, to deliver the best water, sewerage and
                                                                  waste management services to the gold coast community.
                                                                  council’s business activities are addressed under chapters 8 and
                                                                  9 of the local government act 1993. the legislation demands good
                                                                  industry practices and removes the privileges of council ownership
                                                                  in terms of setting prices and conducting business. it also gives the
                                                                  public rights to scrutinise major investment and financial decisions,
                                                                  relating to the good stewardship of public funds, with council
                                                                  required to provide:
                                                                  y performance plans for the coming financial year (prepared
                                                                    and adopted as part of council’s annual operational plan)
                                                                  y annual reports on the previous financial year
                                                                    (annual statement of operations)
                                                                  y independent review of complaints about unfair
                                                                    advantages over competitors, and
                                                                  y independent review of complaints about
                                                                    water and sewerage pricing.
                                                                  in addition to detailing the operations of gold coast waste man-
                                                                  agement and gold coast water, this section of our annual report
                                                                  briefly outlines the activities of council’s smaller businesses. these
                                                                  smaller businesses include council’s tourist parks business, which
                                                                  was identified as a new type 2 business in 2006-07, and the gold
                                                                  coast building certification group, a non-type 3 business.




                                                                  96.2%
                                                                   gold coast waste management
                                                                   customer satisfaction rating




                                                                  $82m
6.0   our
business activities
                                                                   pimpama recycled water
                                                                   treatment plant completed




                                                                gold coast city council annual report 2008-09 105

our financials  community financial report                                                                                                                                              our financials  financial statements




 statement of cash flows                                                            current ratio
                                                                                    the current ratio measures council’s ability to repay its short-term
 building our community equity                                                      debt (due in the coming 12 months) using short-term assets (cash
 the cash flow statement (see page 131) shows council’s cash inflows                and other assets that can be converted quickly to cash). in 2008-09
 and outflows. this statement shows our ability to pay our bills and                council’s short-term assets were four times the value of short-term
 have some money left over for the future. our ending cash balance                  liabilities, a healthy position to be in. council is confident that liabilities
 at 30 june 2009 was $370 million, down 8.4 per cent from the end of                will be paid as they fall due.

            500                                                                     the debt ratio measures the portion of assets that is funded by debt.

                                    year
                                                                                    (such as parks, roads, etc) are recognised as revenue in the financial
    year              2004-05     2005-06      2006-07      2007-08      2008-09    statements, but they do not provide cash that is able to be used to
    cash                                                                            pay off debt or to fund other expenses. therefore, it was decided that
                    315,000,000 306,000,000 377,000,000 405,000,000 370,000,000

 council is continuing to work to ensure it is in a strong financial
 position to provide for the current and future needs of our growing
 community. the keys to achieving this goal are long-term plan-                     interest cover
 ning – and continuing investment – to maintain a strong, financially               this ratio measures how many times the result from ordinary activi-

 impact on council’s capacity to service debt and could be misleading due to its
 volatile and large value.

should interest rates decrease by 1% the impact depicted in the above                           nised depreciable asset prior to the reporting date.
sensitivity analysis would be equal in amount in the reverse direction.


                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          gold coast city council annual report 2008-09 147

our financials  financial statements                                                                                                                                         our financials  financial statements




38. south east queensland water reform                                       (b) water distribution and retail
during 2007-08 the queensland water commission released a report to          further reforms proposed by the queensland water commission include
the queensland government on the urban water supply arrangement              the creation of water distribution and retail businesses for the following
in south east queensland. the report outlined a range of structures          three regions within southeast queensland:
and regulatory reforms for urban water arrangements in south east            (i) brisbane, ipswich, lockyer valley somerset and scenic rim;
queensland, including enhanced economic regulation and pricing.
                                                                             (ii) moreton bay and sunshine coast; and
(a) bulk water                                                               (iii) gold coast, redland and logan.
the south east queensland water (restructuring) act 2007 established         each of the three new businesses will be responsible for the provision
four new statutory bodies, which transferred the control of bulk water       of water, wastewater and recycled water services (inclusive of both
infrastructure from existing local government water businesses.              distribution and retail services) to all customers within the boundaries of
the new entities comprise:                                                   the respective councils. these businesses will be established as separate
                                                                             legal entities with independent boards that report regularly to their
(i) two new bulk water supply authorities, owned by the state govern-        council shareholders.
ment, which control both water storage and manufactured water
facilities;                                                                  gold coast city council is expected to have a controlling interest in the
                                                                             company responsible for the combined region of gold coast, redland
(ii) a state-owned bulk water transmission company to manage the major       and logan.
water grid assets in south east queensland; and
                                                                             commencement of this company, and the transfer of assets and opera-
(iii) a state-controlled water grid manager to operate the water grid and    tions from each council to the new entity, is not expected to occur until
regulate pricing.                                                            1 july 2010.
pursuant to gazetted transfer notices, the council's bulk water assets and   as the impact of these changes is not yet determined, no account has
certain freehold land and employees were transferred to the new bulk         been taken of them in preparing these financial statements.
water supply and transport entities during 2008-09.
compensation for the transfer was received by council in the form of
a retirement in qtc loans and cash. a summary of assets and liabilities
transferred, and the compensation received, is presented below:

                                                                                                            local governments

     legislative                                                                                            section 534(1)(a) of the local government act 1993 requires council
                                                                                                            to report “details of action taken in relation to, and expenditure on,
                                                                                                            a service, facility or activity:




     information
                                                                                                            (i) for which the local government made and levied a special rate or
                                                                                                            charge for the financial year, and
                                                                                                            (ii) supplied by another local government under arrangements
                                                                                                            entered into under section 59”.




and report indexes
                                                                                                            council had no details to report for the year under this section.


                                                                                                            changes to
                                                                                                            council tenders
                                                                                                            section 534(1)(b) of the local government act 1993 requires council
                                                                                                            to report “a list of all action taken under section 488(2) during the
                                                                                                            year”. the following changes to tenders occurred in 2008-09:
                                                                                                            y contract lg314/254/09/015 – citywide supply and
                                                                                                              installation of non-motorised transport counting equipment,
                                                                                                              and data monitoring. date issued december 2008.

                                                                                                              signal maintenance for three years. date issued
                                                                                                              june 2008. tender accepted october 2008.

                                                                                                              centre – electrical supply upgrade. date issued
                                                                                                              april 2008. tender accepted july 2008.

                                                                                                              design, supply and construction of a footbridge and boardwalk.
                                                                                                            y contract lg314/411/09/059 – storage, assembly,
                                                                                                              delivery and maintenance of mobile garbage bins.


                                                                                                            expressions of interest
                                                                                                            section 534(1)(c) of the local government act 1993 requires council
                                                                                                            to report “a list of all resolutions made during the year under sec-
                                                                                                            tion 489(1)” i.e. short-listing after calling expressions of interest. the
                                                                                                            following expressions of interest were called during 2008-09:
                                                                                                            y contract cs433/892/01 – community bicycle hire scheme.


                                                                                                            council registers

                                                                                                            to report “a list of registers kept by it and open to inspection”. the
                                                                                                            listed registers open to inspection are:
                                                                                                            y councillors’ register of interests
                                                                                                            y activities carried on by council’s business entities to
                                                                                                              which competitive neutrality principles apply
                                                                                                            y subordinate local laws (local law policies)

global reporting initiative                                                                                                                                        index of legislative
(gri) content index                                                                                                                                                requirements
the global reporting initiative (gri) is a process that introduces                 indicators                                                                      requirement                                     pages        requirement                                                 pages
globally applicable guidelines that enable an understanding of
an organisation’s contribution to sustainable development. the                     economic indicators                                                   pages     local government act 1993                                    local government finance standard 2005
guidelines are a framework for reporting economic, environmental                   economic performance                                                            section 532(a)                                     128       section 23(2)(a)                                              152
and social performance in relation to sustainability.
